msDesc.head: GREGORY, PETER OF LIMOGES, GROSSETESTE; S. XIV ex.-XV

supportDesc.extent:
160 leaves (ii + 158) 310 210
The edges heavily retrimmed and spattered with red.
supportDesc.collation: a bifolium, 1–312, 410, 512, 64(+ 1 after 4) / 712, 814(11–14 canc.), 910, 108, 116 / 12–1310, 14–1512, 168(2–4 canc.); catchwords. fol. 79 is only one col. wide and written only on the recto.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii, sewn on six bands; formerly chained from the usual position. fols. i and 158 were pastedowns in an earlier binding. At the foot of fol. 158 is the mark of a brass chain-staple.

history.provenance: At least partly made in Oxford.

On fol. 158 are two partly-erased cautio notes, naming M. Thomas Lovkock and the Turvylle chest, the first dated to the Feast of St Mark 1428, the second to the Feast of St Kenelm 1429, also naming M. Walter Colchestre, and giving the secundo folio as at present. Beneath are ‘Memorandum quod M. [Ricardus Pedyngtone]’, smudged and partially erased, ‘Ricardus Flemmyng’, erased, and ‘Memorandum quod ista pecia [signata cum s et h. in dorso above the line] una cum uno libro iacent M. Ric’ [Pedyngtone] nomine M. R[erased] xxiii s. v d. / usque ad finem Trinitatis inclusiue.’ Lovecock (BRUO 1165–6) was fellow of Balliol in 1417, still c. 1422. Pedyngton (BRUO 1451) was fellow of Merton in 1405 and 1411. Colchestre is otherwise unknown. Richard Flemyng (BRUO 697–9) was at the University 1405–6, DTh in 1414, bishop of Lincoln 1419–1431.

On fol. ivis ‘Precium xx. s. iii s. iiij. d. xx. d.’, s. xv, and a table of contents (arts. 1–2, 4, 3) in the same or a similar hand. A later hand has bracketed the titles, corrected their order, and written ‘li 12us’ below, suggesting that the book was in a Merton electio. Inside the front board is ‘N. 7. 2. Art:’, s. xvii, canc. in red, and a sheet of paper with the contents, s. xvii, ‘B. 1. 8 (LXXXII)’ in red, and the College bookplate. The James no.‘160’ is at the head of fol. 1, s. xvii in. ‘2’ is inked on the foredge.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

msItem.author: Gregory
msItem.title: Dialogi
msItem.incipit: Quadam die nimiis quorundam secularium tumultibus depressus
msItem.explicit: si ante mortem Domino ipsi hostia fuerimus
msItem.note: CPL 1713; SChr 251, 260, 265 (1978–80). Each book is preceded by capitula.

layoutDesc.layout: Written space 240 150 , ruled with brown ink in 2 cols of 37 lines.

decoDesc.decoNote: Spasmodic, with many unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics, the latter sometimes supplied in a later hand. Plain blue initials, doubtless meant for flourishing in red, which was only added on fol. 1; alternating red and blue initials in the capitula to bk. 1; rubrication, yellow highlighting.

msItem.note: Composed and delivered at the papal curia in Lyons in 1250 &c
msItem.incipit: (I) Anno Domini millesimo CC quinquagesimo 3 ydus May apud Lugdunum uenerabilis pater Robertus Crosthed Lincolniensis episcopus constitutus in presencia domini pape Innocencii quarti
Dominus noster Iesus Christus eternus eterni Dei Patris Filius de secretissimo sinu eterni Patris
Intelleximus nos litera domini pape recepisse
Nouerit discrecio uestra quod mandatis apostolicis affeccione filiali
In eadem prouincia decem exempli gratia fertilium pascuorum ambitus
(II. 3) Hec parabola non indiget edisseri plana est
(III) Itaque post primo proposita paucis elapsis diebus
(IV) Episcopi Lincoln’ omnibus retro temporibus consueuerunt uicare domos religiosas
(VI. 2) Ysaias ait 29. cap. eo quod appropinquant populus
(VIII. 2) Ad ueram sanctitatem et sapientiam nolo
msItem.finalRubric: Finiunt hi sermones quos ad clerum solummodo proposui. Incipiunt et alii sermones quos generaliter ad omnes protuli et primo de Virgine gloriosa, omnium uiuencium infallibili exemplari. Lovekoc

handDesc.handNote: Two anglicana formata hands, the first to fol. 90vb line 28, the second, less proficient, of Lovekoc. Doubtless this was Thomas Lovecock (BRUO 1165–6), fellow of Balliol in 1417, still in c. 1422, still alive in 1431 (see below).

decoDesc.decoNote: Blue initials flourished in red; red or yellow highlighting early on.
